importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when demolition of the White House East Wing began, marking the official start of the construction of the new ballroom.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The project began in 2024 and is ongoing in 2025, fulfilling a 15-year ambition by President Trump to expand the White House's entertaining facilities.

keyTakeAways: Demolition of the White House East Wing began on October 20, 2025, to make way for a new $200 million, 90,000-square-foot ballroom.
The new ballroom, designed with gold and crystal features, will have a seating capacity of 650, significantly larger than the current East Room.
The project is part of President Donald Trump’s broader effort to redesign the White House grounds and architecture to reflect his personal style, including gold finishes and large flagpoles.
Trump claims the ballroom will be 'in keeping' with the White House’s architectural heritage and will be funded by private donors and Trump himself.

The construction process has drawn criticism, with some calling it excessive or inappropriate, prompting White House officials to reference past renovations during the Truman administration as precedent.
White House officials, including press secretary Karoline Leavitt and communications director Steven Cheung, have defended the project as necessary modernization and evolution of the building.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Demolition of the White House East Wing began on October 20, 2025, as part of a $200 million project to construct a new 90,000-square-foot ballroom, which will seat 650 people and feature gold finishes, crystal chandeliers, and gilded architecture. The initiative, long championed by President Donald Trump, aims to fulfill a 15-year ambition to expand the White House’s entertaining capacity and reflect his personal style, including elements reminiscent of his private clubs. The project has sparked controversy, with critics calling it excessive, prompting White House officials to invoke past renovations during the Truman administration as precedent. The ballroom will be built adjacent to the existing structure, not replacing it, and will maintain architectural harmony with the neoclassical design of the White House, though it will be funded by private donors and Trump himself.
title: Demolition begins to replace White House East Wing with Trump’s ballroom
